content.webTitle: New images at National Portrait Gallery

fields.headline: New images at National Portrait Gallery
fields.bodyText: The National Portrait Gallery yesterday acquired two Mrs Joplings, striking images of women separated by over a century, but who managed dual careers as artists and socialites. One is a self portrait by the artist photographer Sam Taylor-Wood - wife of White Cube gallery owner and contemporary art dealer Jay Jopling - and the other a superb portrait by the Pre-Raphaelite painter Sir John Everett Millais of his friend, the painter Louise Jopling. Both were acquired with grants from the Art Fund. The heritage lottery fund also gave £240,000 towards buying the Millais from a private collection. Sam Taylor-Wood works in photography, film and video. However the large print she made last year is called Self-portrait in Single Breasted Suit with Hare - a bleak joke about her recent treatment for cancer. The Millais portrait of Louise Jopling is regarded as one of his greatest portraits. It marks his move from his Pre-Raphaelite period to a more sombre, introspective style. He completed the painting - as a present for her son, his godchild - in five marathon sittings, and Mrs Jopling complained of the exhaustion of maintaining the bold upright standing pose for hours on end. She was herself a notable painter, and a campaigner for women's rights and votes well into the 20th century. Curator Peter Funnell said it filled a gap in the gallery's collection. "This is a tremendous acquisition - we weren't able to borrow this portrait for the Millais exhibition a few years back, and it was probably the most glaring omission."
